subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
This word is possibly related to {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*g-la(ŋ/k)||bird of prey}}, which is likely a loan from {{der|zh|mkh-pro|*laŋ ~ *laaŋ ~ *laiŋ||large raptor}} > {{cog|mkh-ban-pro|*klaːŋ||hawk}}, {{cog|mkh-pal-pro|*klaaŋ||kite}}, {{cog|mnw|လနေၚ်||kite}}, {{cog|km|ខ្លែង||kite}}; within Tibeto-Burman, compare {{cog|bo|གླག||eagle; vulture}}, {{cog|my|လင်းတ||vulture}}, {{cog|kac|lang||bird of the falcon family}} ({{zh-ref|Benedict, 1972}}; STEDT).

This word agrees better with {{cog|bo|སྐྱིང་སེར||eagle; vulture}} if the Old Chinese is reconstructed as ''*s-ki̯əŋ'' ({{zh-ref|Benedict, 1990}}; {{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}); {{zh-ref|Benedict (1976)}} reconstructs {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*s-kiŋ}} for this, which {{zh-ref|Benedict (1990)}} suggests is the native {{cog|sit}} root.
